header.title: The Picatrix Ġāyat al Hakim - The Goal of the Wise

central_thesis: The Picatrix, presented through this edited text, is a foundational medieval grimoire that synthesizes diverse ancient sources to provide a comprehensive operative system of celestial and talismanic magic, enabling practitioners to engage planetary and lunar energies for a wide range of practical effects, underpinned by a macrocosmic-microcosmic philosophy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction to The Picatrix and Steven Ashe's Contribution
structure_content.summary: This section introduces Steven Ashe's background and involvement with Qabalah and Hermetic traditions, presenting his role as editor of this version of The Picatrix. It establishes The Picatrix as an 11th-century Arabic text of uncertain authorship, drawing on Greek, pre-Islamic Arabian, Ismaili, and Nabataean sources, and highlights its influence on later Western magicians like Agrippa and Paracelsus.

The core philosophy is detailed, emphasizing the Macrocosm and Microcosm, where the human mind can control universal energies by petitioning divine aspects corresponding to planetary powers. Specific planetary influences on human affairs are outlined, such as Saturn for prosperity/ruin, Jupiter for wealth, Sun for health, Venus for love, Mercury for learning, and Moon for visions. Eugenio Garin's commentary on the unity of reality and correspondences is also included.

structure_content.chapter_title: General Principles of Planetary Engagement (Book Three Chapter Five)
structure_content.summary: This part outlines the fundamental requirements for successful planetary magic. It stresses the necessity of knowing a planet's spirit, resonance, color, smell, associated foods, and ensuring auspicious astrological timing (correct planetary position, absence of eclipses). Instructions for constructing talismans are provided, specifying appropriate metals and geometric divisions (a T-shaped cross for various magical purposes, such as invincibility or protection).

General guidelines for invoking planetary powers are given, focusing on the practitioner's state (submission to divine will, purity of heart and attire) and identifying the planet best suited for the purpose. This section also introduces the concept of wearing appropriate robes, using specific incenses, and aligning operations with the planet's sympathetic hour. The principle 'That which is above is like that which is below' is cited.

This section provides extensive details for Saturn. It covers the planet's secret nature (covert operations, sorrows), traditional depictions (Apollonius, Agrippa, Aristotle), the name of its spirit (BRIMAS) and its six parts, specific materials (gems like onyx, obsidian, lodestone; metals like lead, iron), plants, drugs, intoxicants, sacred animals, and colors (indigo, black). It includes a full invocation text and an incense recipe.

This section details Jupiter's influences (collecting money, fixing visions, calming sorrows), the sign of granted requests (burning flame in coals), its spirit's name (DAMAHOS) and its parts, other names (MUSHTARI, BARGEES), and traditional depictions (man on eagle, human on chair). Correspondences include gems (aquamarine, corundum, sapphire), metals (tin, zinc), plants (walnuts, almonds, pine nuts), and intoxicants (sweet-smelling incenses). Two invocations are provided.

Mars is presented as the source of engaging power, ruling natural science and surgical medicine. Its secret nature involves seducing hostility and defeating enemies. Correspondences include sacred geography (strongholds, riots), materials (red brass, sulfur, ruby, garnet, onyx; gold, burning oil, red copper), and scents (red sandalwood). Depictions (warrior with sword/shield, man on lion with spear) and specific invocation instructions (red attire, sword, copper ring, frankincense in copper brazier) are given. Its spirit name is DAGHDIYOS, and two invocations are provided, including one for revenge against enemies.

The Sun is described as the light of the world, source of nourishment, ruling philosophy and divination. Its secret nature embodies solemnity, nobility, and willpower. Correspondences include gems (red rubies, goldstones, diamond), metals (pure gold), plants (palm tree, grapevines, saffron, rose), intoxicants (aloes wood, sandalwood), and animals (camels, horses, snakes, peacocks). Depictions (woman in chariot, beardless man with crown) are mentioned. Its spirit name is BANDALOS, and an invocation and complex incense recipe are provided.

Venus is portrayed as the source of desire, governing poetry and literary arts. Its secret nature is linked to the formulation of souls, happiness, and protection from evil. Correspondences include gems (pearls, lapis, emerald), metals (tin, copper, silver), plants (basil, henna, saffron, roses), intoxicants (elderberry, seeds of ban), and animals (camels, deer, doves). Depictions (upright woman with apple/fan, maid with brush/apple) are noted. Its spirit name is DIDAS, and invocation instructions (white robes, golden ring, mirror, apple, wine, perfume in silver/gold brazier) are given along with two invocations.

Mercury is the source of intellectual power, ruling deductive reasoning, debates, philosophy, and writing. Its secret nature involves revealing secrets and diplomacy. Correspondences include jewels (engraved stones, aquamarine), metals (mercury, tin, marble), plants (sugar cane, cotton, pepper, carnation, basil), intoxicants (ginger, Valerian, hashish), and animals (camels, wild asses, monkeys, birds). Depictions (naked man on eagle writing, man with staff and cat) are provided. Its spirit name is BARHOYAS, and an invocation and incense recipe are included.

The Moon lights the planets and is the source of Nature's power, governing land surveying, water, mathematics, and conversational arts. Its secret nature facilitates planetary orbits and reveals secrets. Correspondences include sacred geographies (spring waters, lakes, snow), gems (small pearls, moonstone, quartz), metals (silver), and intoxicants (cinnamon, pepper, ginger). Depictions (woman on two oxen, knight riding a hare) are discussed. Its spirit name is GHARNOS, and an invocation and incense recipe are detailed.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Mansions of the Moon (Book One Chapter Four)
structure_content.summary: This critical section describes the 28 Lunar Mansions, each defined by specific celestial degrees (e.g., Al-Sharatain from Aries 0 to 12°51'26"). For each mansion, its ruling spirit (e.g., Geriz, Enedil, Annuncia) and specific magical purposes are enumerated, ranging from promoting harmonious relationships and safe travel to destroying crops, strengthening prisons, finding treasures, or causing discord. This provides a detailed framework for timing and intent for talismanic operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Rules for Planetary Interaction and Protection
structure_content.summary: This concluding section offers aphorisms and rules for effective planetary magic, including the longer-lasting duration of fixed star charms compared to planetary charms, the importance of aligning the rising sign with the request, and when to use a solitary planet versus a combination. It provides guidance on seeking protection from specific planets for different needs (e.g., Jupiter for wealth, Mars for defeat, Venus for burdens, Mercury for knowledge, Sun/Moon for general righteousness/speedy response, Saturn for banishment). It also details which planets refuse to cooperate with others in certain actions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Additional Planetary Correspondences (Summarized from Steven Ashe's Section)
structure_content.summary: This section, distinct from the Picatrix excerpts, provides a concise list of correspondences for Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, The Sun, Venus, Mercury, and The Moon. Each entry includes Angels, Spirits, Animals, Metal, Stone, Day of the Week, Magical Properties, Number, Colors, Names (according to Bruno's Cantus Circaeus), Dignifications, and Cornelius Agrippa's comments on the images of each planet, offering alternative or supplementary information for practitioners.

key_concepts.definition: A foundational medieval Arabic grimoire of celestial and talismanic magic, known as Ġāyat al Hakim or 'Goal of the Wise', synthesizing various ancient magical traditions.

Celestial intelligences or archetypal forces associated with the planets, which can be invoked and directed through ritual and talismanic magic to influence terrestrial affairs consonant with their nature.
The 28 divisions of the Moon's daily path through the zodiac, each with unique magical virtues, specific degrees, and a ruling spirit, used to fine-tune magical operations for diverse purposes.

A core practice involving the creation of consecrated objects (talismans) from specific metals and gems, inscribed with symbols and images at astrologically auspicious times, to embody and direct celestial influences for desired outcomes.

A fundamental Hermetic concept asserting that the universe (Macrocosm) and humanity (Microcosm) are mirrors of each other, allowing for influence on the greater through manipulation of the lesser and understanding of correspondences.

The principle that objects or actions resembling a desired effect, or things that were once in contact, can influence each other; applied in choosing materials, images, and actions that are 'consonant' with planetary natures.

The critical practice of performing magical operations during specific planetary hours, when planets are in favorable positions (e.g., ascending, not eclipsed), or when the Moon is in a particular mansion, to ensure alignment with desired celestial energies.

practical_system.description: The practical system detailed in The Picatrix revolves around the invocation of planetary spirits and the utilization of Lunar Mansions for creating talismans and performing other magical operations. It is a system deeply rooted in astrological timing and sympathetic magic, aiming to manipulate macrocosmic energies through microcosmic actions. Success hinges on a precise alignment of the practitioner's intent, the planetary or lunar influence, specific materials, and ritual actions.
tools: Planetary Talismans (made from specific metals like lead, tin, gold, copper, mercury, silver)
Planetary Gems and Stones (e.g., onyx for Saturn, sapphire for Jupiter, ruby/garnet for Mars, carbuncle for Sun, emerald for Venus, achates/aquamarine for Mercury, moonstone/quartz for Moon)
Planetary Incenses (specific recipes using herbs, resins, animal products, e.g., aloe, myrrh, saffron, basil, cinnamon)
Symbolic Objects (e.g., sword, mirror, apple, book, staff)
Seven Stones/Gems (for influencing multiple people or environments, representing each planet)
rituals: Planetary Invocations: Reciting specific invocations to individual planetary spirits (e.g., BRIMAS for Saturn, DAMAHOS for Jupiter, DAGHIDYOS for Mars, BANDALOS for the Sun, DIDAS for Venus, BARHOYAS for Mercury, GHARNOS for the Moon) to petition for requests aligned with their nature.

Talisman Creation: Constructing talismans using metals specific to the ruling planet (e.g., lead/iron for Saturn, tin/silver for Jupiter, iron/brass for Mars, gold for Sun, copper/silver for Venus, mercury/tin/marble for Mercury, silver for Moon). These are inscribed with images (e.g., Lion/Snake for Mars, enthroned self for advancement) and geometric patterns (a T-shaped cross), precisely timed to planetary hours and optimal astrological alignments.

Ritual Attire: Wearing robes of colors sympathetic to the target planet (e.g., green for Saturn, white/yellow for Jupiter, red for Mars, red/gold/yellow for Sun, white for Venus, mixed colors for Mercury, white for Moon).

Incense Offerings: Burning specific incense blends (e.g., Armenian incense/juniper/tar tree seed for Saturn, chestnut/ebony/bush-grass/myrrh for Jupiter, whortleberry/bush-grass/aloe/pepper for Mars) in a brazier made of the corresponding planetary metal, within an enclosure open to the sky.
Symbolic Actions: Holding symbolic items during invocation (e.g., a book for Mercury, a sword for Mars, a mirror/apple for Venus) to enhance resonance.

Lunar Mansion Operations: Performing rituals when the Moon is in a specific mansion, chosen for its particular virtues (e.g., Al-Sharatain for safe travel, Al-Botein for hidden treasures, Al-Jabhah for love between man and woman).

relevant_quotes.text: The Picatrix represents the earliest literary attempt to synthesize the formalities of esoteric practice associated with sympathetic magical operations such as the production of talismans and the invocation of spiritual powers by means of lyrical exposition.

The work's point of departure is the unity of reality divided into symmetrical and corresponding degrees, planes or worlds: a reality stretched between two poles: the original One, God the source of all existence, and man, the microcosm, who, with his science (scientia) brings the dispersion back to its origin, identifying and using their correspondences.

In order to successful y engage any planetary power to benefit your affairs it is necessary to call upon its Spirit and become knowledgeable about the nature and resonance of each planet's influence within the microcosm. Thus one will become acquainted with each planet's colour and smell ; become physically sensitive to its resonances by consuming the food associated with the plants and animals falling under that planet's influences.

A talisman should be constructed from the metal specific to that planetary power which should be divided into three section marked by the spaces within and around a T- shaped cross with the top empty of form; the lower half divided by a vertical line. If you desire invincibility in warfare you might inscribe thereupon a Lion or a Snake; to be safe in adversity you might employ a picture of a bird; for advancement in career matters you might use an image of yourself enthroned or to punish others an image of them lying before an image of yourself enthroned.

That which is above is like that which is below and that which is below is like that which is above. By the performance of these rites the influence of the heavens may be felt in the world of action and the influence of the world of action may be felt in the heavens which give themselves to those sympathetic to their nature.

The charms of the fixed stars are of more lasting duration that the charms of the rotating planets. If you can substitute the power of a wandering star for a fixed star of the same nature you would have the chance to gather greater influence.

critical_analysis.relevance: This edited version of The Picatrix is highly relevant for scholars and practitioners of Western Esotericism and Occultism. It provides an invaluable window into the historical development of ceremonial magic, demonstrating the deep influence of Arabic magical texts on later European grimoire traditions. The text's detailed correspondences, invocations, and practical instructions offer a working model of planetary and lunar magic, making it a critical resource for understanding the operative mechanics of such systems. It shows the intellectual synthesis involved in medieval magic, blending philosophy, astrology, and ritual to achieve desired effects.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of advanced practitioners of ceremonial magic, particularly those interested in traditional grimoire work, planetary magic, and talismanic creation. It is also suitable for academic researchers and historians of esotericism and occultism seeking primary source material contextualized for modern study. Due to the complexity, the extensive lists of correspondences, and the inherent nature of grimoire material (including references to potentially ethically challenging operations like curses in the original context), it is not recommended for beginners without a strong foundation in occult ethics and practice.
